stories.text:
Hello,

I'd like to ask you for advice regarding career in programming. I'm currently a first year student in software engineering (informatyka stosowana) at Polish university. In future I'd like to try my luck at finding an apprenticeship, so that after I'm done with studies I will have some experience.

How should I prepare for that task? I know that the common advice for this is grinding Leetcode (i.e in general algorithms theory and so on) and having a good Github portfolio. But I've seen people being divided on that one, as I often found voices saying that most likely it is harmful. Related to that, what constitutes a good project to show? I've been toying with ideas of making games in C++ with some graphic library, but all my ideas seem derivative.

What would be the tasks I would do as an apprentice? I know that this depends of a looooot of things, but on average what would I be expected to do? (our teachers often scare us that our only job would be making coffee).
stories.title: Ask HN: How to prepare for finding your first apprenticeship?
‘White gold’: why shrimp aquaculture is a solution that caused a problem

stories.text: Discord isn't compatible with Europe's protection laws; we cannot report or denounce it without leaking personal information. I'm searching for a Mac or Dev Tools script to check and delete (my own) Discord messages on public servers in a fast way, with supervision.
stories.title: Ask HN: A script to delete public Discord messages

stories.text:
Last months were economic roller coaster, I figured out that this topic is something I (and most people) need to learn more about.

Many of the market movements this year where predictable, and people who "knows" are able to avoid the impact (or even profit).

Examples:

- COVID => Rise in medicine stocks and Dip in tourism stocks

- Rise of remote work => Dip in rent in SF / Vancouver etc..

- less COVID restrictions => more demand on Oil

- Higher Oil price => higher cost for international shipping => higher price of imported goods

- Chip shortage => higher price of cars and devices (even if used)

- Kremlin invades Ukraine => Dip in Crypto/Stocks and Rise in Gold/Silver

- No WWIII => Dip in Gold/Silver and Rise in Crypto/Stocks

- Economic Sanctions on Russian Oil => Rise in energy prices in Sanctioning countries vs Dip in non-Sanctioning countries

- High inflation data released => expectations of interest rate rise => Dip in Gold/Silver/Crypto/Stocks/currencies not backed by USD

- Higher interest rate => Less demand on mortgages => Slower growth for real estate market

I'm not happy that I only know about these AFTER they happen.. What to do/study/follow to be aware of such market movements before the impact actually propagate, so I can prepare?

Thanks in advance
stories.title: Ask HN: Online resources to study/follow market dynamics for beginners?
